The app now even guides personal reflection towards specific categories. title: Excellent attention to detail
review:
I bumped into Stoic accidentally, when I was browsing App Store Stories, and after I became intrigued by its inspirations (i.e. Ancient Greek and Roman Stoicism) and its pretty graphics I downloaded it on a whim. To my real surprise, I loved it! I think what sets it apart from other journaling and mood-tracking apps (I‚Äôve found no alternative that I can like as much as Stoic, and believe me, I have tried) is 1) its structural simplicity and coherence and 2) its honesty and its nonjudgemental tone. You never feel like the app is pushing you to feel a certain way, because it seems like it‚Äôs just giving you tools to help you understand yourself; the routines it suggests seem to cleverly adapt to how much effort you feel like putting in that day; and I never once felt like it was trying to press me or trick me into paying money (I bought premium anyway). The developer has clearly put thought into the app‚Äôs design, and it shows.

I‚Äôm looking forward to seeing this app mature. One personal suggestion I have for it is that I think personalisation of routines could allow for a little more flexibility. I bought the subscription partly out of a desire to support the development of the app, and partly because I wanted to customise the morning and evening routines. In particular, I‚Äôm not a big fan of the ‚Äòwhat is your main focus today?‚Äô and the ‚Äòhow did you feel today?‚Äô questions, mostly because they usually don‚Äôt offer answer options that suit me. I realise there‚Äôs quite a bit of structure (follow-up questions, trend tracking etc.) built around the answers to those questions, but I was hoping I could write my own questions for the morning/evening routines and choose arbitrarily which parts of the default routine I want to keep. (Custom questions wouldn‚Äôt have to have functionality like generating new questions and contributing to the trends tracker‚ÄîI‚Äôd be happy if I could write my own non-adaptive text and multiple choice questions.) Making it possible to add and delete answer options in the ‚Äòwhat is your main focus today?‚Äô and ‚Äòhow did you feel today?‚Äô questions is another option, and I have a feeling a lot of people would like to see that happen.

In summary: really good app, and I hope it preserves the principles of forthrightness and attention to detail that I‚Äôve come to appreciate seeing in all its design decisions. I hope it grows a community going forward, and I‚Äôd love to be a part of it.

title: Love the app, just needs some minor improvements
review:
Been using Stoic since I discovered it earlier this year, and overall I absolutely love it, I've stuck with it and it really helps me put my day and my life in order and perspective. The look of the app is gorgeous, the functionality is smooth, and I really do feel more prepared for my day after doing my morning routine, and the evening routine helps me go to bed with a clear head. 

That all said, there's one thing that annoys the heck out of me that I really hope the devs will be able to fix (and given how well they've handled adding new features and improving the app regularly, I'm sure this is something they can do): Often, especially during the morning routines, I will get repeat questions. For example, the app will ask me 'How do you plan to spend your day?', and then immediately or one or two questions later, it will ask 'What are you planning to do today?'. Or, like this morning, it asked me to list things I am grateful for today, and then immediately after asked me again to list 3 things I am grateful for. 

I realize the questions are triggered by the things we mark down as our focus for each day, and some of them may apply to multiple categories, but being asked the same question multiple times when I've already answered it for the day really annoys me and takes me out of my relaxed and focused mindset. If that could be fixed, so that you don't get the same or very similar questions in the same session, or at the very least some kind of indicator whether a question was triggered by, say, 'work' and then a similar question was triggered by 'reading' or 'learning', so that I can tailor my answers to those specific topics of focus, that would immediately elevate my rating to 5 stars. 

Other than that, *love* the app, and really hopeful that this slight annoyance will be fixed.
